title-group.article-title: Sesquiterpenoids and furan derivatives from the Orychophragmus violaceus (L.) O.E. Schulz endophytic fungus Irpex lacteus OV38

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Sesquiterpenoids and furan derivatives from the
Orychophragmus violaceus
(L.) O.E. Schulz endophytic fungus
Irpex lacteus OV
38

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Huai-Zhi Luo a, b , Huan Jiang a , Bing Sun a , Zhen-Nan Wang a , Ai-Qun Jia
b, *

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
a
School of Environmental and Biological Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, 210094, China

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
b
School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Engineering Research Center for Utilization of Tropical Polysaccharide Resources, Ministry of Education, Hainan University, Haikou, 570228, China

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Sesquiterpenoid
Furan derivatives
Anti-inflammatory activity
ABSTRACT

Nine undescribed compounds, including six tremulane-type sesquiterpenoids, irpexolaceus A-F, one phenolic bisabolane-type sesquiterpenoid, irpexolaceus G, and two furan derivatives, irpexonjust A-B, as well as eight known analogs, were isolated from an endophytic fungus (
Irpex lacteus OV
38) of
Orychophragmus violaceus
(L.) O. E. Schulz, a Chinese medicinal and edible plant. The structures of these natural compounds were elucidated based on NMR, HRESIMS, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and ECD spectroscopic data. Among the tested isolates (50 μ g/mL), the inhibitory effects of irpexolaceus A, C, D, F, and G, irpexonjust B, and irpexlacte B against NO release from LPS-induced RAW 264.7 cells were higher than 45%, while irpexlacte C (42.6%), irpexolaceus B (39.6%), irpexonjust A (43.7%), and irpexolaceus E (33.6%) exhibited weaker inhibitory effects on the release of NO.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
In this study,
Irpex lacteus OV
38 was isolated from healthy flowers

and stems of
Orychophragmus violaceus
(L.) O.E. Schulz ( Brassicaceae ) plants growing in a garden at the Nanjing University of Science and Technology ( China ). Six undescribed tremulane-type sesquiterpenoids, irpexolaceus A-F ( 1 , 5 , 9 , 12 , 13, and 16, respectively), one undescribed phenolic bisabolane-type sesquiterpenoid, irpexolaceus G ( 17 ), and two undescribed furan derivatives, irpexonjust A-B ( 10 and 11 ), along with three known sesquiterpenoids and five known furan derivatives ( Fig. 1 ), were isolated from the fungus
I. lacteus OV
38. These isolates were evaluated for their inhibitory activity against nitric oxide (NO) production in lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced RAW 264.7 cells.

sec.title: 2. Results and discussion
sec.p: Multiple fermentations and ethyl acetate (EtOAc) extractions yielded a total of 99.49 g of crude extract. The nine undescribed isolates and eight previously reported analogs were isolated by various methods, including silica gel, C 18 reversed-phase silica gel, and Sephadex LH-20. The undescribed isolates were analyzed as follows:

Irpexolaceus A ( 1 ) was obtained as a colorless oil. The molecular formula was identified as C 15 H 20 O 2 , with six degrees of unsaturation based on the HRESIMS data ( m/z 233.1527 [M + H] + , calcd for C 15 H 21 O 2 , 233.1536). In addition, the 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 1 ( Table 1 ) showed structural similarity to tremutin F (
), with the key difference being the absence of a hydroxyl binding to C-4 ( δ C 21.8) in compound 1 . The NOESY signals ( Fig. 2 ) of Me-13 ( δ H 0.79)/H-8 β ( δ H 1.59)/Me-14 ( δ H 1.14) and H-7 ( δ H 3.11)/Me-15 ( δ H 1.06)/H-8 α ( δ H 1.83), as well as the lack of H-7/Me-14 and H-8 β /Me-15 correlation signals, supported the assignment of Me-13 to α orientation, opposite to that of H-7 ( β orientation). The predicted electronic CD (ECD) curve of 1 was calculated using the quantum chemical method at the B3LYP/6-31 + G (d, p) level and the theoretical ECD curve for 6 R ,7 R showed excellent agreement with the experimental one ( Fig. 3 ). Therefore, the absolute configuration of 1 was identified to 6 R ,7 R .

Irpexolaceus B ( 5 ), a colorless needle-like crystal, was assigned the molecular formula C 15 H 22 O 3 , with five degrees of unsaturation based on the HRESIMS data ( m/z 251.1638 [M+H] + , calcd for C 15 H 23 O 3 , 251.1642). The 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 5 ( Table 1 ) showed high similarity to the co-isolate irpexolactin J ( 8 ) (
). The NOESY correlations ( Fig. 2 ) of Me-13 ( δ H 1.03)/Me-14 ( δ H 1.09)/H-1 ( δ H 2.96) and H-6 ( δ H 2.14)/H-7 ( δ H 2.10)/H 2 -15 ( δ H 3.36, 3.33) suggested that Me-13, Me-14, and H-1 were on the same orientation and different from H-6, H-7, and H-15. Considering the differences in 5 and 8 regarding optical rotation and retention time ( t R ) for HPLC analysis, they were determined as stereoisomers. The absolute configuration of 5 was established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis ( Fig. 4 ) and unequivocally determined to be 1 S ,6 R ,7 R ,9 S .

Irpexolaceus C ( 9 ), a colorless oil, was identified with a molecular formula of C 20 H 27 NO 5 , with eight degrees of unsaturation based on HRESIMS data at m/z 362.1960 [M+H] + (calcd for C 20 H 28 NO 5 , 362.1962). The 1D and 2D NMR spectra exhibited the same relative configuration to compound 5 , except for the C 5 moiety, which was an ester of 5 at C-15, as the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 5 ) showed a correlation between H 2 -15 ( δ H 4.00, 3.97) and C-16 ( δ C 174.1), and the carbon signal at δ 71.7 in compound 5 shifted downfield to δ 74.2 in compound 9 .

Irpexonjust A ( 10 ) and irpexonjust B ( 11 ) were obtained as yellowish powders, with the same molecular formula of C 12 H 18 O 4 and four degrees of unsaturation based on HRESIMS data at m/z 227.1278 [M+H] + (calcd for C 12 H 19 O 4 , 227.1278) and 227.1277 [M+H] + (calcd for C 12 H 19 O 4 , 227.1278), respectively. The 1D NMR data of 10 ( Table 2 ) demonstrated high similarity to irpexlacte D (
), with the main difference being that the carboxyl at C- 11 in irpexlacte D was substituted by a hydroxyl in compound 10 , as determined by the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-8 ( δ H 2.76)/H 2 -9 ( δ H 1.83, 1.74)/H-10 ( δ H 1.49)/H-11 ( δ H 3.75)/H-12 ( δ H 1.16), and HMBC correlations from H-11 ( δ H 3.75) to C-9 ( δ C 25.1), C-10 ( δ C 39.4), and C-12 ( δ C 23.5) ( Fig. 5 ). Compared to 10 , the hydroxyl of 11 was located at C-10 rather than C-11, as confirmed by the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H 2 -8 ( δ H 2.89, 2.79)/H 2 -9 ( δ H 1.88, 1.74)/H-10 ( δ H 3.47)/H-11 ( δ H 1.50)/H-12 ( δ H 0.93), and HMBC correlations from H 2 -8 ( δ H 2.89, 2.79), H 2 -9 ( δ H 1.88, 1.74), H-11 ( δ H 1.50), and H-12 ( δ H 0.93) to C-10 ( δ C 72.9) ( Fig. 5 ). The planar structures of 10 and 11 are given in Fig. 1 . Unfortunately, stereochemical determination using the Mosher method proved difficult due to the limited amounts these compounds.

Irpexolaceus D ( 12 ) and irpexolaceus F ( 16 ) were isolated as yellowish oils, and assigned the same molecular formula of C 15 H 22 O 4 , with five degrees of unsaturation based on HRESIMS data at m/z 267.1584 [M+H] + (calcd for C 15 H 23 O 4 , 267.1591) and 289.1412 [M+Na] + (calcd for C 15 H 22 NaO 4 , 289.1410), respectively. The 1D NMR data of 12 ( Table 1 ) were highly similar to davotremulane B (
). The NOESY correlations ( Fig. 2 ) of Me-14 ( δ H 1.10)/H-5 ( δ H 3.83)/H-7 ( δ H 2.12) and Me-13 ( δ H 1.03)/H-1 ( δ H 2.86)/H 2 -15 ( δ H 3.34, 3.32) indicated the same orientation of Me-14, H-5, and H-7, different from Me-13, H-1, and H-15. The absolute configuration of 12 was determined to be 1 S ,5 R ,6 S ,7 S ,9 R using single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis ( Fig. 7 ). Compound 16 had the same molecular formula as davotremulane B but differed in the configurations of C-1 and C-6 based on the NOESY correlations ( Fig. 2 ) of Me-14 ( δ H 1.05)/H-1 ( δ H 3.08)/Me-13 ( δ H 1.16) and H-15 ( δ H 3.33, 3.32)/H-7 ( δ H 2.05)/H-5 ( δ H 4.71). The calculated and experimental ECD spectra of 16 showed excellent fit ( Fig. 6 ), indicating that the absolute configuration of 16 was 1 R ,5 S ,6 R ,7 R ,9 R .

Irpexolaceus E ( 13 ) was obtained as a yellowish oil, with a molecular formula of C 15 H 22 O 4 , and five degrees of unsaturation based on HRESIMS data at m/z 267.1586 [M+H] + (calcd for C 15 H 23 O 4 , 267.1591). The 1D NMR data of 13 ( Table 1 ) were similar to 12 , with the main difference being that hydroxyl was bound to C-10 rather than C-15. This was corroborated by the HMBC correlations ( Fig. 5 ) from Me- 14 ( δ H 1.04), Me-15 ( δ H 0.91), H 2 -8 ( δ H 1.60, 1.55), and H-1 ( δ H 2.73) to C-10 ( δ C 83.5), and the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlation between H-10 ( δ H 3.62) and H-1 ( δ H 2.73). The relative configuration of 13 was determined by the NOESY correlations ( Fig. 2 ) of Me-13 ( δ H 0.96)/H-1( δ H 2.73) and H- 5 ( δ H 3.71)/H-7 ( δ H 1.93)/H-10 ( δ H 3.62) combined with single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis ( Fig. 7 ). The absolute configuration of 13 was 1 S ,5 R ,6 S ,7 R ,10 S .
a Recorded in CD OD. 3 b Recorded in CDCl.

The 3-(4,5)-dimethylthiahiazo(-2)-3,5-diphenytetrazoliumromide (MTT) assay (
) was used to evaluate the cytotoxic effects of the nine undescribed isolates and 3 and 4 on RAW 264.7 cells. When the concentrations of compounds 3 , 4 , 11 , and 16 were > 100 μ g/mL, cell viability was less than 80%. Therefore, these test compounds were considered non-cytotoxic to RAW 264.7 cells after 24 h of incubation at low concentration (25 and 50 μ g/mL) (Fig. S106). We further evaluated the inhibitory effects of these compounds on NO production in LPS-induced RAW 264.7 cells. Results showed that NO release was suppressed after exposure to compounds 1 , 3 , 9 , 11 , 12 , 16 , and 17 (concentration of 50 μ g/mL), with an inhibitory ability in the order 17 (56.7%) > 11 (55.7%) > 16 (50.2%) > 1 (49.8%) > 3 (48.8%) > 12 (47.3%) > 9 (45.8%). Compounds 4 (42.6%), 5 (39.6%), 10 (43.7%), and 13 (33.6%) exhibited weaker inhibitory effects on NO release ( Fig. 10 ).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: b Recorded in CDCl.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 3 a Recorded in CD OD.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p:
In this study, nine undescribed compounds, including six tremulane-type sesquiterpenoids, one phenolic bisabolane-type sesquiterpenoid, and two furan derivatives, along with eight previously reported analogs, were isolated from the metabolite composition of endophytic fungi
I. lacteus OV
38. The structures of these isolates were assigned based on

NMR, HRESIMS, IR, UV, ECD, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. Eleven isolates, including 3 and 4 , were evaluated for anti-inflammatory activity by detecting their inhibitory effects on NO production in LPS-induced RAW 264.7 cells. At a concentration of 50 μ g/ mL, compound 17 (56.7%), one phenolic bisabolene-type sesquiterpenoid, and compound 11 (55.7%), with a hydroxyl binding to C-10, not to C-11 (as in 10 ), exhibited remarkable inhibitory effects against NO release compared to the other nine isolates. The inhibition of NO production by compound 16 (50.2%) was stronger than that by compound 12 (47.3%), which showed the same planar structure but different absolute configurations (compound 16 , 1 R ,5 S ,6 R ,7 R ,9 R ; compound
12 , 1 S
,5 R ,6 S ,7 S ,9 R ). Furthermore, with its double bond between C-1 and C-10, compound 1 (49.8%) exhibited a higher inhibition ratio than compounds 12 (47.3%) and 9 (45.8%). Therefore, 17 and 11 could be considered as potential compounds for further anti-inflammatory studies.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p:
Optical rotations were measured with an Autopol VI Automatic Polarimeter (PerkinElmer, Waltham, MA, USA ). UV spectra were obtained with an Evolution 220 UV–Vis Spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Madison, USA ). IR spectra were obtained with a Nicolet™ IS10 FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Madison, USA ). The NMR images were generated with either a Bruker AV-500 (Bruker Corporation, Karlsruhe, Germany ) or Bruker Avance III 600 MHz spectrometer (Bruker Corporation, Karlsruhe, Germany ). HRMSESI analysis was recorded on a Q-Exactive Orbitrap MS system (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Bremen , Germany ). Silica gel (100–200 and 200–300 mesh, Qingdao Marine Chemical Factory, Qingdao, China ), C 18 reversed-phase silica gel (YMC Co., Ltd., Kyoto , Japan ), and Sephadex LH-20 (GE Healthcare Bio-Sciences AB, Uppsala , Sweden ) were used for column chromatography (CC). Fractions were monitored by TLC (HSGF 254, Yantai Jiangyou Silica gel Development Co., Yantai, China ), and spots were visualized by 10% H 2 SO
4 in
methanol, in combination with HPLC LC-20AT (Shimadzu, Kyoto , Japan ) equipped with an XB-C18 column (100 × 2.1 mm , 3 μ m, flow speed = 1 mL/min, Welch Ultimate, Shanghai , China ). Preparative HPLC was performed using HPLC LC-20AT (Shimadzu) equipped with a YMC-Pack ODS-A column (250 × 10 mm , ID, S-5 μ m, 12 nm , flow speed = 2–3 mL/min, YMC Co., Ltd., Kyoto , Japan ).

sec.title: 4.2. Culture and fermentation of endophytic fungi
sec.p:
The endophytic fungal strain OV38 isolated from
Orychophragmus violaceus
(L.) O.E. Schulz ( Brassicaceae ) was identified as
Irpex lacteus (Fr.) Fr. (Phanerochaetaceae)
according to previous research (
). The fungal strain was cultivated on potato dextrose agar (PDA, Sangon Biotech, Shanghai , China ) medium at 25 ◦ C for 7 days, and large-scale fermentation was performed in Fungus No. 2 medium (2% sorbitol, 2% maltose, 1% glutamine, 1% glucose, 0.3% yeast extract, 0.05% tryptophan, 0.05% KH 2 PO 4 , 0.03% MgSO 4 , pH 6.4, autoclaved at 121 ◦ C for 15 min) at 28 ◦ C and 140 rpm for 15 d (
).

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p: The fermentation broth and fungal biomass were separated by centrifugation at 17 696× g at 4 ◦ C for 15 min, and then extracted three times with the same volume of EtOAc. The EtOAc residue was fractionated by CC over a silica gel (100–200 mesh) column eluted with a gradient system of CH 2 Cl 2 /MeOH (100:0–0:100) to obtain 14 fractions (Fr. A-M).

Fr. A ( 19.6 g ) was further separated by silica gel CC (200–300 mesh) with petroleum ether/EtOAc (20:1–1:1) and EtOAc/MeOH (100:1–10:1) gradient systems to obtain six sub-fractions, i.e., Fr. A1-A6. Fr. A3 ( 450 mg ) was separated by Sephadex LH-20 (100% MeOH) and purified by HPLC LC-20AT equipped with a YMC-Pack ODS-A column to give 1 and 2 ( 13.5 mg and 18.8 mg , 75% MeOH, flow speed = 3.0 mL/min, t R = 20.5 min and 22.0 min, respectively). Fr. A6 ( 4.79 g ) was subjected to CC over silica gel eluted with a gradient system of CH 2 Cl 2 /MeOH (80:1–0:100) to give five sub-fractions, i.e., Fr. A6.1-A6.5. Fr. A6.1 ( 97.4 mg ) was further purified by preparative HPLC to give 3 and 4 ( 40.1 mg and 5.0 mg, 45% MeOH, flow speed = 2.5 mL/min, t R = 31.0 min and 33.0 min, respectively), and Fr. A6.4 ( 2.55 g ) was separated by repeated CC of silica gel and Sephadex LH-20 (100% MeOH) to yield 5 ( 670.7 mg ). Fr. A5 (2.0 g) was separated by CC of Sephadex LH-20 (100% MeOH), and then purified by preparative HPLC to give 6 ( 4.7 mg , 46% MeOH, flow speed = 2.5 mL/min, t R = 10.5 min), 7 , 5 , and 8 (11.3, 15.3, and 10.3 mg , 68% MeOH, flow speed = 3 mL/min, t R = 10.0, 14.5, and 16.4 min, respectively).

Fr. F ( 5.63 g ) was separated by CC over silica gel eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 / MeOH (100:0, 40:1, 20:1, 10:1, and 0:100) to give ten sub-fractions, i.e., Fr. F1–F10. Fr. F6 ( 2.72 g ) was separated by CC of Sephadex LH-20 (100% MeOH), and then purified by preparative HPLC to give 9 ( 34.9 mg , 50% MeOH, flow speed = 2.5 mL/min, t R = 48.0 min), 10 , and 11 (2.0 and 3.2 mg , 45% MeOH, flow speed = 2.5 mL/min, t R = 14.5 and 16.5 min, respectively).

Fr. G ( 37.30 g ) was separated by CC over silica gel eluted with a gradient system of CH 2 Cl 2 /MeOH (100:0–0:100) to give nine sub-fractions, i.e., Fr. G1-G9. Fr. G1 ( 7.35 g ) was separated by CC over C 18 reversed-phase silica gel eluted with MeOH/H 2 O (5:1–0:1), and then further purified by Sephadex LH-20 (100% MeOH) to yield 12 ( 27.7 mg ) and 13 (51.0 mg). The remaining fractions were purified by preparative HPLC to give 14 and 15 (32.4 and 23.3 mg , 30% MeOH, flow speed = 2.0 mL/min, t R = 11.0 and 14.5 min, respectively). Fr. G2 ( 7.76 g ) underwent repeated CC over silica gel and Sephadex LH-20 (100% MeOH) and was purified by preparative HPLC to give 16 ( 30.2 mg , 50% MeOH, flow speed = 2.5 mL/min, t R = 25.3 min).

Fr. J ( 4.31 g ) was separated by CC over silica gel eluted with a gradient system of CH 2 Cl 2 /MeOH (80:1–0:100) to give five sub-fractions, i.e., Fr. J1-J5. Fr. J2 (984.0 mg) was separated by Sephadex LH-20 (100% MeOH) and purified by preparative HPLC to give 17 (18.0 mg, 55% MeOH, flow speed = 3.0 mL/min, t R = 12.7 min).

sec.title: 4.4. Spectroscopic data
sec.p: Irpexolaceus A (1) . Colorless oil; [ α ]24 D +27.6 ( c 0.18, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 272 (3.92) nm; CD (MeOH) 195 (Δ ε 6.05), 220 (Δ ε +5.45) nm; IR(KBr): υ max 2956.34, 2931.75, 1743.82, 1651.73, 1450.60, 1034.62 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (500 MHz in CDCl 3 ) and 13 C NMR (125 MHz in CDCl 3 ) data, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 233.1527 [M+H] + (calcd for C 15 H 21 O 2 , 233.1536).

Irpexlacte B (3). Yellowish oil; [ α ]24 D 19.8 ( c 0.09, MeOH); CD (MeOH) 195 (Δ ε +4.08), 228 (Δ ε 0.51), 251 (Δ ε +0.65), 288 (Δ ε 2.36) nm; 1 H NMR (500 MHz in MeOD) and 13 C NMR (125 MHz in MeOD) data, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 183.0997 [M+H] + (calcd for C 10 H 15 O 3 , 183.1016).

Irpexlacte C (4). Yellowish oil; [ α ]27 D +19.8 ( c 0.14, MeOH); CD (MeOH) 195 (Δ ε +1.47), 245 (Δ ε 0.14), 280 (Δ ε +1.65) nm; 1 H NMR (500 MHz in MeOD) and 13 C NMR (125 MHz in MeOD) data, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 183.0994 [M+H] + (calcd for C 10 H 15 O 3 , 183.1016), 205.0813 [M+Na] + (calcd for C 10 H 14 NaO 3 , 205.0835).

Irpexolaceus B (5). Colorless needle-like crystal; [ α ]24 D 12.5 ( c 0.19, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 221 (4.27) nm; CD (MeOH) 195 (Δ ε +18.76), 220 (Δ ε 1.98), 320 (Δ ε 0.08) nm; IR(KBr): υ max 3430.26, 2925.42, 2862.21, 1732.25, 1660.41, 1447.31, 1029.80 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (500 MHz in MeOD) and 13 C NMR (125 MHz in MeOD) data, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 251.1638 [M+H] + (calcd for C 15 H 23 O 3 , 251.1642).

Irpexolaceus C (9). Colorless oil; [ α ]24 D 39.3 ( c 0.10, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 220 (3.86) nm; CD (MeOH) 195 (Δ ε +4.66), 236 (Δ ε 1.53), 260 (Δ ε +0.14) nm; IR(KBr): υ max 2938.47, 2870.04, 1744.30, 1700.43, 1221.68 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (500 MHz in MeOD) and 13 C NMR (125 MHz in MeOD) data, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 362.1960 [M+H] + (calcd for C 20 H 28 NO 5 , 362.1962).

Irpexonjust A (10). Colorless oil; [ α ]24 D +2.2 ( c 0.13, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 287 (3.82) nm; CD (MeOH) 195 (Δ ε +0.58), 310 (Δ ε 0.54), 358 (Δ ε +0.05) nm; IR(KBr): υ max 3420.58, 2933.20, 1668.12, 1512.40, 1039.44 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (500 MHz in MeOD) and 13 C NMR (125 MHz in MeOD) data, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 227.1278 [M+H] + (calcd for C 12 H 19 O 4 , 227.1278).

Irpexonjust B (11). Colorless oil; [ α ]27 D +22.1 ( c 0.12, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 288 (4.19) nm; CD (MeOH) 195 (Δ ε 0.43), 219 (Δ ε +3.14), 320 (Δ ε 1.50), 375 (Δ ε +0.02) nm; IR(KBr): υ max 3405.67, 3938.50, 1668.12, 1511.14, 1038.96 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (500 MHz in MeOD) and 13 C NMR (125 MHz in MeOD) data, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 227.1277 [M+H] + (calcd for C 12 H 19 O 4 , 227.1278).

Irpexolaceus D (12). Yellow oil; [ α ]24 D 4.3 ( c 0.23, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 220 (4.13) nm; CD (MeOH) 195 (Δ ε +11.57), 235 (Δ ε 6.36) nm; IR(KBr): υ max 3392.65, 2936.57, 2866.67, 1731.94, 1661.37, 1444.90, 1633.66, 984.00 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (500 MHz in MeOD) and 13 C NMR (125 MHz in MeOD) data, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 267.1584 [M+H] + (calcd for C 15 H 23 O 4 , 267.1591).

Irpexolaceus E (13). Colorless oil; [ α ]24 D 24.9 ( c 0.23, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 219 (4.23) nm; CD (MeOH) 195 (Δ ε +4.89), 235 (Δ ε 1.39) nm; IR(KBr): υ max 3396.99, 2960.67, 2890.31, 2871.97, 1727.91, 1658.48, 1033.18, 983.52 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (500 MHz in MeOD) and 13 C NMR (125 MHz in MeOD) data, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 267.1586 [M+H] + (calcd for C 15 H 23 O 4 , 267.1591).

Irpexolaceus F (16). Colorless oil; [ α ]24 D +12.0 ( c 0.08, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 216 (3.97) nm; CD (MeOH) 195 (Δ ε +16.54), 218 (Δ ε 9.07), 306 (Δ ε +0.02) nm; IR(KBr): υ max 3437.01, 2932.23, 2869.56, 1727.42, 1658.48, 1033.66 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (500 MHz in MeOD) and 13 C NMR (125 MHz in MeOD) data, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 267.1594 [M+H] + (calcd for C 15 H 23 O 4 , 267.1591), 289.1412 [M+Na] + (calcd for C 15 H 22 NaO 4 , 289.1410).

Irpexolaceus G (17). Colorless oil; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 293 (3.62) nm; IR(KBr): υ max 3437.01, 2932.23, 2869.56, 1727.42, 1658.48, 1033.66 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (500 MHz in MeOD) and 13 C NMR (125 MHz in MeOD) data, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 281.1379 [M+H] + (calcd for C 15 H 21 O 5 , 281.1384).

sec.title: 4.5.1. Irpexolaceus B (5)
sec.p:
Crystal data for Cu 5_0m . C 15 H 22 O 3 , M = 250.32, a = 6.1771(4) Å, b = 10.8746(8) Å, c = 20.1591(16) Å, α = 90 ◦ , β = 90 ◦ , γ = 90 ◦ , V = 1354.16(16) Å 3 , Z = 4, T = 170.0 K, space group P 212121 , μ (Cu Kα) = 0.672 mm 1 , Dcalc = 1.228 g /cm 3 , 27 650 reflections measured (8.772 ◦ ≤ 2 θ ≤ 149.070 ◦ ), 2772 unique ( R int = 0.0404, R sigma = 0.0180), used in all calculations. The final R 1 was 0.0370 (
I >
2 σ ( I )). The final wR 2 was 0.1069 (
I >
2 σ ( I )). The final R 1 was 0.0380 (all data). The final wR 2 was 0.1087 (all data). The goodness-of-fit on F 2 was 1.044. Flack parameter = 0.08(5), determined using 1101 quotients [(I+)-(I-)]/[(I+)+(I-)]. CCDC: 2095200 (www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

sec.title: 4.5.2. Irpexolaceus D (12)
sec.p:
Crystal data for Cu 12_0m. C 15 H 22 O 4 •H 2 O, M = 284.34, a = 6.6041 (2) Å, b = 13.4644(4) Å, c = 16.6640(4) Å, α = 90 ◦ , β = 90 ◦ , γ = 90 ◦ , V = 1481.77(7) Å 3 , Z = 4, T = 170.0 K, space group P 212121 , μ (Cu Kα) = 0.779 mm 1 , Dcalc = 1.275 g /cm 3 , 10 023 reflections measured (12.492 ◦ ≤ 2 θ ≤ 149.180 ◦ ), 2946 unique ( R int = 0.0332, R sigma = 0.0279), used in all calculations. The final R 1 was 0.0324 (
I >
2 σ ( I )). The final wR 2 was 0.0846 (
I >
2 σ ( I )). The final R 1 was 0.0332 (all data). The final wR 2 was 0.0853 (all data). The goodness-of-fit on F 2 was 1.117. Flack parameter = 0.05(6), determined using 1175 quotients [(I+)-(I-)]/[(I+)+(I-)]. CCDC: 2095201 (www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

sec.title: 4.5.3. Irpexolaceus E (13)
sec.p:
Crystal data for Cu 13_0m. C 15 H 22 O 4 , M = 266.32, a = 8.81161(5) Å, b = 10.5996(6) Å, c = 31.0482(18) Å, α = 90 ◦ , β = 90 ◦ , γ = 90 ◦ , V = 2899.9(3) Å 3 , Z = 8, T = 170.0 K, space group P 212121 , μ (Cu Kα) = 0.711 mm 1 , Dcalc = 1.220 g /cm 3 , 20 199 reflections measured (14.262 ◦ ≤ 2 θ ≤ 155.282 ◦ ), 3055 unique ( R int = 0.0394, R sigma = 0.0237), used in all calculations. The final R 1 was 0.0341 (
I >
2 σ ( I )). The final wR 2 was 0.0864 (
I >
2 σ ( I )). The final R 1 was 0.0350 (all data). The
final wR 2 was 0.0875 (all data). The goodness-of-fit on F 2 was 1.063. Flack parameter = 0.12(5), determined using 1258 quotients [(I+)-(I-)]/[(I+)+(I-)]. CCDC: 2095205 (www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

sec.title: 4.6. ECD calculation
4.7. Cytotoxicity assay
sec.p:
The RAW 264.7 cells (8 × 104 cells/well) were cultured with Dulbecco’ s Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM, Gibco, Utah , USA ) supplemented with 10% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (Hyclone, Utah , USA ) in an incubator with 5% CO 2 at 37 ◦ C for 12 h until the cells adhered to the wall. After this, another 100 μ L of DMEM was added to each well in the presence of test compounds using the 2-fold dilution method (from 100 to 1.5625 μ g/mL) (
), with 0.1% DMSO used as the negative control and DMEM medium without any compounds used as the blank group. The plates were incubated for 24 h at 37 ◦ C. A 20- μ L aliquot of MTT ( 4 mg /mL) was added to each well for 4 h incubation at 37 ◦ C. The supernatant was carefully removed and 200 μ L of DMSO was added to each well with gentle shaking to fully dissolve the purple crystal formazan, followed by determining at 570 nm on a microplate reader (Biotek Elx800, Winooski, VT, USA ).

sec.title: 4.8. Nitric oxide (NO) production assay
sec.p:
NO production was determined using the Griess reagent assay (
), with slight modification. The RAW 264.7 cells (8 × 10 4 cells/well) were treated with test compounds (25 and 50 μ g/mL) in the presence of LPS (1 μ g/mL) for 24 h at 37 ◦ C in 96-well plates. Cells treated with LPS only were used as a model group and cells in DMEM without compounds or LPS were used as a blank group. The RAW 264.7 cell culture supernatant was harvested for analysis with Griess reagent. After incubation for 15 min at room temperature, the optical densities were measured at 550 nm . The concentration of NO was estimated according to the standard curve of sodium nitrite. All values are given as means ± standard deviation (SD). Data analysis involved one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with subsequent Scheffe’ s test.
Funding
This work was supported by grants from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (82160664) and the Natural Science Foundation of Hainan Province (221CXTD434).

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p:
The authors thank Ph.D. Xishan Huang for ECD calculation analysis ( Guangxi Normal University) and Prof. Yu Zhang for the supplement of compounds related spectra ( Kunming Institute of Botany )
.

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112996.
